sentence: And out when you only have just.
A story to share.
Please welcome them to the stage along with our moderator, Marina Tapier.
Leslie, Charles, welcome to this route.
Oh, I'm happy to be here.
So we're going to talk about how to raise your first check and how to pitch at Inception.
Firstly, I understand they were the first check into some very seminal companies.
Tell me what it is about them that you found interesting.
I think it's Gusto, Flexport, Robin Hood and Plaid.
I'm very lucky.
You know, it's very fascinating.
I was very fortunate.
Started my career out as one of the first four founding partners of GB or Google Ventures, and I helped them build up their seed program back when they were doing seed.
And you know, back then were just looking for amazing founders, folks that reminded me of Larry Sergey, who had a vision for the world that it would change if whatever they did came true.
And so that was one of the things were looking for back then.
You have no information.
Most of Gusto, most of Plaid, most of Flexible, were all ideas in the back of the napkin.
So that made it really fun to just sort of banter with them and truly understand how they thought the world would change.
So, you know, when they described the vision of Gusto where Everybody could have $4 payroll, that was amazing because the payroll experience was terrible at that point.
And so, you know, I said, like, let's just find a way to work together.
And we wound up writing them the first check through Google.
So very fortunate to sort of meet these amazing folks with great visions.
Charles, you invested pre seeds, so this is exactly what you do.
What do you look for in founders?
You know, about two thirds of the people we back are first time founders, which feels very kind of against the current moment where I think everyone's obsessed with repeat founders.
But most of the people we back, first time founders, pre product market fit, pre launch, as we say at work, pre everything.
So Wesley's one of the few people I know who has the courage to continue to back people at the earliest stage.
But I'm usually looking for a couple things.
A founder who knows something special and unique about the problem they're solving.
Also someone who has zero to one startup experience.
So it works a lot better if you spend time at a startup with 25 or fewer people before you do zero to one.
And then there's got to be a market where it feels like there's some inflection point happening.
I'm going to interrupt here because I actually like what he said.
You have to be able to really, truly understand 0 to 1.
Most people say, oh, I got this grand vision at the end, but at the beginning they're like, I don't know how to get started.
I need an investor's help.
And that's a challenge, right?
You don't ever want to be investing.
At least I don't invest in founders that come and say, I need my investors help to run my business.
And that zero to one stage is really important.
So what Charles said really about somebody has a clear vision and a clear ability to articulate what it takes to get from 0 to 1.
And then for me, from 1 to 100 or 100 to a billion.
That's where like you, I really lean in and say, like, look, you've got this figured out.
How can the money turbocharge your business?

I mean, we've learned the hard way, as in we've lost money by backing people who've had amazing careers at really large organizations where they have all of this ability to navigate politics and to figure out systems and get their hands on resources.
Then you put them in a room with no management, no instructions, no PRD, no OKRs, and a whiteboard and say, you figure it out.
And it's paralyzing for them because all the things that made them successful and they're really fancy, big job don't apply to 01.
And then there's another challenge, which I noticed when investing very early on, is that folks from larger companies, there's a lot of infrastructure that solve that for this.
Like, folks that, you know, come to me and say, hey, I worked at Google for 10, 20 years.
Or if they're like working and managing this product, they sort of assume that there's distribution, right?
Google has incredible distribution that was solved in the early days.
And I got to play a very fantastic role learning how to solve distribution.
But like, you ask them about, hey, how will you get 100 users, 100,000 users, 10,000 users, or even a million users?
And then, you know, the infrastructure just isn't there.
And so, you know, I think that zero to one stage, as you pointed out, is a very complicated thing.
And it doesn't work well for people who haven't had the ability to go build that or learn from the start.
What did you say to a Google employee or meta employee who want to start a startup, given everything you just said, like, how can they get there?
I think it takes.
And maybe this is like a little meta, like, no pun intended.

It takes a certain amount of self awareness to say I can appreciate all of the resources I had at Meta, I had the brand, I had other people around, I had an IT department when my laptop broke, I had access to all of this distribution.
And to be able to say, I recognize to Wesley's point, I'm not going to have all of these advantages.
And I think you also have to care.
I've met a lot of people who are doing very well at big companies.
Like, well, I want to do a startup, but I kind of want to make 75% of what I make as an L whatever at this big company.
And I'm like, do you want comfort or do you want an adventure?
Because starting a company from scratch is like not comfortable.
I don't want to display it is not easy, it is not control, but it's an adventure.
So usually I'm trying to find out, does this person want to go on an adventure.
And anyone who's been an adventures are not up and to the right.
Adventures are up and down and sometimes the down is really hard.
And I frankly met a lot of people at big companies where at the end of the meeting I'm like, I think you would be happier if you stayed where you were.
The resources you have available to you at your company are pretty significant.
And I don't know that the idea that you're talking about is worth walking away from.
Wesley, would you bet this up on somebody who is coming out of Google or Meta or one of the large companies?
So the answer is yes.
And there's actually one exception on generally what Charles said, which is, you know, sometimes people are too comfortable at large companies.
There's a.
They've worked on something where they have a unique insight about why the thing is completely broken.
Like, that's actually what, what I look for is what unique insight do we have?
I was very lucky to have back to Canva and the Series A when 111 people said no, you know, nobody knew what they were building.
And back then the product looked like a print shop, right?
Like you would go use it to make a set of business cards or you go use it to make a brochure for something and then you'd not use it again.
Their churn was very high.
But both Cliff and Nell totally understood what the unique insight was about why tools, the incumbents were all broken.
And they basically said, look, you know, people under 35, like they grew up with a phone in their hands.
It's image first, there's a camera built into the Phone.
The tools that are available to people, the things that were trained on, like Office or like Photoshop, they're like text first, right?
Like, it's called Microsoft Word, for heaven's sake.
So they basically said, like, we need to build something that is design and image first.
That piece needs to happen.
It wasn't until social media they had the immigration, the Canva Pro, where they turned on monetization and where people started using it constantly for both social media and their homework.
They nailed the distribution and they got people using it.
But that unique insight was so clear in their head that nobody else understood.
Most investors said, there's no way you're going to like ever disrupt Microsoft Office.
There's no way you're going to disrupt these tools.
I was trained on for 35 years.
And what they didn't understand was the next generation was growing up going, I want design.
I don't want to spend four years in yearbook class learning how to use Adobe tools so I can go into them.
So that's the piece I look for.
You worked on something of such a unique insight, and that unique insight says I, this is broken.
My company will never solve it.
There's too much going in the way.
It's the same reason I was very fortunate to be on the team that helped to buy YouTube for Google.

I looked, I was on the ads team at that point and we looked at it and you know, Google had its own tool, but Google was building it for pleasing all of the people that were like running media companies, they had drm.
It was such a friction.
Full tool to use has so much friction.
And then comes YouTube where they had unique insight going.
You can upload any video, cat videos, piano videos, whatever you want.
And there was no friction in doing it.
And Google said like, oh, that's the right approach and that's why, you know, that deal went through.
So we look for the unique insight.
And this is the piece that I, I care deeply about.
It's like, what is it that's broken that you feel that your company or that you're so motivated to go fix that you have this unique insight into it.
I have one thing.
About half of the founders in our portfolio are spinning out of a company where to wealthy's point, they encounter some friction.
Sometimes it's a project that they really wanted to build and management didn't give them the resources.
And so we look for people who've kind of banged into that problem.
And oftentimes those people are not C suite People, they're individual contributors.
They're product managers, they're engineers.
They're not leadership.

So we're always on the hunt for people who are actually in the trenches building stuff or accounting for problems and saying, wow, I think this problem is bigger than my boss and my boss's boss realized that this is something we could take out of our company and maybe build it for the industry.
What do you look for founders, where there's no product and no traction?
That's like 90%.
Yeah, 90% of like everything.
Conception stage, like, I'd have no product, no traction.
But do they have like an mvp?
Do they have something because it's so easy to build this things now?
Well, it's easy.
It's easy now, but it wasn't easy 10 years ago.
And that's perfectly fine.

I'd rather have a person that understands clearly what the insight is and what they're doing is going to change the world than a person who has an MVP that's still trying to discover a bunch of things and figure out why they're going to have product market.
I think it's maybe useful to contextualize, like what Wesley and I do every day.
We're going to meet thousands of companies a year, each of us, and we're going to meet most of them for, I don't know about you, 30 minutes for a first meeting.
And usually in the first seven to 10 meeting minutes, I kind of know, does this person, is this person interesting?
Do they have insights on this problem that feel novel?
And I hope I can leave you out with this idea of like, novelty.
Sometimes people present me ideas and I'm like, okay, I'm a generalist.
I knew nothing about this idea in the meeting space.

You tell me the problem, my brain starts going through, well, how would I solve this problem as a generalist if I don't learn anything new that wasn't kind of obvious that a smart person can reason their way through?
I go, one of two things is probably true.

Either this person hasn't studied the problem deeply enough to understand an interesting angle that sounds different than the other 10 people who pitched me on it, or this is a trivial problem to solve and there's no big business to be built here.
The one cabinet add to that I care deeply about.
This is a very big first principle.
The thinking for everyone at my firm needs to argue this one when they want to go bring a deal through, which is, how is your company going to be?
Monopoly, Right?
Like you Know, it's a dirty word for people say anti trust and everything else.
But like monopolies are great, especially if you're a natural monopoly or a government granted monopoly.
Some of my best companies that I've been very fortunate to back in the seed stage were biotech companies.
But it's a natural monopoly.
I mean it's a government granted monopoly.
You have a patent on the drug.
If the drug makes it through clinical trial, you get whatever 17 years minus the time it takes you to get the drug.
Drug through clinical trial is a government granted monopoly.
Why drug prices are so expensive?
Because you control the pricing.
There's no other competitor.
And so, you know, Google became a sort of a natural monopoly, right?
Like the product built.
Most people don't understand that monopoly matters.
If you have 40 competitors and you have, you're one of 40 legal AI companies, for example, suddenly the pricing goes down to zero.
You don't control the pricing or the distribution.
And I'm sympathetic.
I think sometimes as an investor you will see 40 of the same idea and the founder knows about three people doing the same thing.
So there's this weird asymmetry of information where the founder is like, well, we have some competitors.
There's people out there doing it.
He was an investor.
Like I've seen 10 times as many people doing this as you think are doing it.
So would you bet on somebody who is one of the 20 companies that going after the same use case?
We're seeing a lot of this in AI.
I haven't succeeded on this, but you know, I may be an idiot.
It's really hard.
We've certainly gone.
I mean you'll hear VC say oh, it's a red ocean.
You know, it's a crowded competitive environment where lots of people have lost money.
We've certainly gone into some of those markets and been successful.
I think you have to understand, well, what is it that this company understands that those other companies don't?
And oftentimes the answer is nothing.
They all actually think the same thing.
And I have a really hard time investing.
Everybody believes the same thing because it means everybody's going to go after the same distribution channels with the same business model.
All of their marketing copy is going to feel the same.
But sometimes you do find a really disruptive, interesting company in a space that people have kind of either written off or assumed was solved.
But it's really hard.
I wouldn't wish that life on anybody in this room.

So by not betting in one of the 10 companies going after whatever is the use Case A couple weeks ago I saw, I think it was three or four companies that ditched me on customer research is exact same use case.
Like all the Series A investors, they all went up for the use case because it's probably very promising.
But if you don't bet on it, does it mean that you think there's only going to be one category winner?
I mean, theoretically there could be several, right?
There could also be zero.
And I think this is the thing people forget.
Everyone's like, some categories don't produce a lot winner either because competition drives everything down to zero.
It's a race to the bottom.
Sometimes there's no winner because it turns out the unit economics for the business don't work for anyone.
Like you just there can be no winner.
I mean, I still remember, I mean, history repeats itself a lot, right?
During the pandemic when everybody thought that we'd be stuck indoors forever.

And I mean, there were a hundred different conferencing companies, like, remember all the online conferencing companies, all conferences going doors, this, this thing where we're all together in the same room was never going to happen again.
And all of them didn't do well, right?
There was no winner.
And then I still remember, on every block in New York City, there was a 50 minute grocery delivery company full of these people of ebikes and people were raising at these outrageous valuations.
There's one company that pitched to me going, I don't even remember the name.
And it's like, oh, we're raising at a 4 billion valuation for 50 minute grocery delivery.
I kind of look out at my door going like, well, there's like 10 of them on my block, right?
Like where else all of them are like kind of like gone.
So sometimes there are no winners in folks where there's a lot of hype and no monopoly and intense competition because you just can't make money off of it.
Also, we're not like perfect forecasters.

If you had told me that Zoom would have an integrated meeting recording function, like literally built into the product with a button you could push and that you would have otter fireflies, granola and a bunch of Avoma, I could go on that there would be a robust ecosystem of meeting recording tools when the leading meeting platform had a literally like a big red button, I would have said there's no way you can overcome the embedded distribution that Zoom has with the product.
They are the meeting platform for most people.
And it turns out that there's a lot of other people who Want more functionality or different things.
And there are so many of those.
I don't know.
Every time I join a meeting I'm like, oh, this is a new meeting.
I've never seen this one before.
There's so many of them.
And that to me, like would have defied initial logic that there were meaningful businesses to be built there.
So Granola and Otter and Firefly are examples of the same company.
I mean, the same use case.
They're just going after it in a different way.
So maybe founders could try a different flavor or whatever is the tech du jour.
We have lots of tech du jour right now.
What, what are you looking like, is there a specific industry that you're looking for right now?
Like, is what is.
I know why tech is very interesting for you, but in software/AI, what.
Are you looking for?
Oh man.
I mean, like, as a generalist, I look for, you know, founders with unique ideas.
I still remember doing Canva.
I remember meeting them in Sydney and it was one of those things where I wasn't looking for a productivity software tool.
In fact, I was told to run away from the space.
There were hundreds of people doing slideshare slides for sales, like Foxen type things.
And I sat there going, why don't we have another productivity company?
But one of my founders, I was very lucky to have been on the board of investment.
These guys are exceptional thinkers.
Just take the eff in meeting.
So I, I did.
I was like blown away by their like unique vision, their insight and like what they were building and just like really like saw their 100 year plan, right?

Like this is something I look that the best founders have 100 year plans and really, truly understand why they want to go build something where the world is so fundamentally different in five years, 10 years, 100 years.
Larry Sergey, who I had the good fortune of working on, working with very early on.
I joined Google when there were hundreds of people.
They had a hundred year plan, right?
Their vision was so, just crystal clear, but also so grand.
And so that's what I look for is founders.
That.
And it could be in any sector where there's life sciences, a drug for cancer, it could be a knee replacement drug that somebody's working on.
Like these things just sort of pop out of nowhere.
So I always keep my mind open for what that 100 year plan, you know, world thing that changes the world in five or ten years is.
So there's nothing.
I really sit there and go like, oh, I won't do I always take an interesting pitch once and again.
There needs to be some signal from somebody usually that I know that tells me this founder has such a unique insight on this.
Like you should take the meeting that, you know, I'll always keep that in mind.
Charles, are you also a generalist?
I'm a generalist too and I, this is my time where I don't actually.
Know what I'm going to like until.
I get into a meeting.
People say, what should I send you?
I'm like, so what's his point?
Like send me great people.
So at the end of the day, I'm not really an expert on any technology area.
I'm trying to find people who have expertise and I usually find that people have expertise.
That expertise shows up fairly early on.
In a meeting or conversation.
It could be their domain expertise.
It could be somebody know about the problem, it could be somebody that they teach me.
And so I'm always, I go to these meetings thinking I'm going to learn something from this founder and if what I learned is profound, I'm probably going to invest.
And if I don't, it's just going to go in the back of my brain as a new piece of knowledge I can use for the next meeting.
And many times the founder pitches you a company that completely changes when they succeed, right.
I still remember Robin Hood the guys came in with.
They actually brought chats with them, right?
Name of the company called Cash when I wrote the check in the Robinhood and they were pitching a hedge fund algorithmic trading platform that would give like people data advantages for hedge funds.
That was the pitch.
But like they were so freaking smart and eventually the idea they couldn't make money selling the data, but they could, I mean they couldn't make money just like doing a pure data play.
And they, their data wasn't like specific enough.
So they had to create Robinhood to generate that data.
They could do the forward flow.
But that was an insight that I didn't understand at that point or that I didn't understand the data be able to pivot.
So there's a lot of luck in this business too.
But they were just clearly very smart with a very unique thinking on the space.
And you know, I was fortunate enough to be able to say yes at that early stage.
Like there's just a little bit of a spark in an interesting insight on something where I sat there going like, huh, what if they're right?
How important is pedigree?
Having gone to one of the top.
Schools, zero for me, zero Canva has no pedigree.
That was actually one of the things, the founders of Canva don't have a pedigree that every.
Anyone from Silicon Valley index, right?
They were like Mel was a Europe teacher in high school.
Clifford his co founder, was a history teacher.
They went, they came from Perth, they didn't work at Google, Facebook, Meta.
They didn't come from like 20 startups previous company that they created Fusion Books which was a Canva for yearbooks.
Didn't do well, right?
Like that company was just kind of sputtering along and like, you know, a lot of people in Silicon Valley wrote them off.
In fact, I was told by a lot of people, oh, don't waste your time with them.
They don't have the pedigree.
They're from Australia, they're from Sydney.
They haven't worked at a major tech company.
They haven't seen what Silicon Valley is like.
They don't understand the ambition, the drive and the behaviors that people in San Francisco or in Mountain View or wherever we're doing, they're just not the right fit for us.
And here they are the most valuable companies in the world because they created their own culture and they truly understood how to build something differently than anyone in the world was pursuing.
And the other thing about Silicon Valley is back then people were forcing people.
You got to make money, you got to do enterprise sales.
This is your go to market motion.

And the go to market motion they had was all bottoms up people like in high school or in college doing homework, such a unique motion and such a unique insight that they wound up succeeding because everybody was building a tool for you to use that TechCrunch or to use at Goldman Sachs or IBM.
And they built a tool that said we're just going to make it easy for anyone that wants to go do their homework to go do it really well.
So that was a, that was one of those examples and it, the example where a lot of people were misled because they were looking for pedigree.
Charles, what about you?
We don't focus on it at our firm.
I think pedigree is an intellectual shortcut which sometimes leads you to good decisions, but oftentimes leads you astray.
And I think as we talked about earlier, sometimes working at Google or Meta is a good thing.
Sometimes it's not helpful to what you're building.
But I think the reason investors focus on pedigree is it's one really fast way to cut through the noise.
If you've got thousands of pitches in your inbox.
It's an easy sort, but like, easy doesn't always mean good.
And so I always get nervous if someone leads with their pedigree.
It's like we're to Google and I'm like, okay, but what are you building?
And how does like, the fact that you worked at Google or went to seminar, how does that like, map at all to give you an advantage or an edge in understanding this problem?
And many of our most successful portfolio founders don't have the pedigree markers that people looked for.

They, to Wesley's point, they weren't repeat founders who'd had huge exits, they didn't go to a very narrow set of schools, they didn't work at the very narrow set of companies that investors focus on.
But there's a set of firms who are like, very pedigree obsessed.
And I think part of it's because it's a lot easier to deploy large amounts, lots of capital if you reduce everything to a pedigree.
The, the thing, the challenge of pedigree also is not only misleading sometimes or lazy.
It's, it's, it's, it actually forces a set of baggage.
Yeah, right.
Like, oh, all the people in this pedigree are doing this.
I need to go do this.
Right.
Like, people who have pedigree follow the specific path for a reason.

And if you think about startups, some of the best founders are there to destroy whatever the standard, as always, and then do something completely brand new, undeniable before, and sort of figure out, you know, something that, that people with pedigree or people that are in status quo or people that are following their herds would never even think of doing because there's such a high rate of failure or it's something that could cause shame or it's something that like, you know, you just like, hasn't been done before.

And that's, you know, the thing that those are the companies where I've been fortunate enough to see these outlier outcomes, having been in this business, this for so long, is that, you know, the people, pedigree sometimes have such a unique insight or thinking in the world.
They weren't like held back by all the baggage that everybody else, you know, pedigree feels like they have to do.
And there's the other flip side with that.
People with the pedigree are sometimes really afraid to take the right risk or fail.
They'll take the safe path.
I'll target enterprise software Instead of bottomless approach.
Right.
You know, the easier path sometimes is not the best path because it, you know, doesn't lead to.

I do think though, if I were in the shoes of people in the audience, I'd be, well, then how come everybody I read about, not in TechCrunch but in like other applications, it seems like they all went to Stanford or Harvard and all were to Google.
And I think it's because pedigree gives you unfair access to investors.
I think that's the one thing you get with pedigree.
You probably worked with, went to school with, or have a social connection to an investor.
If you come from one of these pedigree institutions, which means your ability to bubble to the table top of somebody's inbox or priority queue is much greater.
It doesn't necessarily mean your idea is better, but that access does impact who gets meeting sometimes and ultimately who gets considered.
So it sounds like you're open to lots of different things.
There are lots and lots of founders.
How do you pick a meeting?
What do you, what do you mean?
Some of this goes back to what Wesley said.
If someone whose judgment I trust tells me I should meet somebody and can provide me with the metadata as to why I should meet them, I'll probably take the meeting.
Unless I have an investment in a competing category or it's a category where I've made investments and concluded I will never invest again.
And then I reserve some portion of my day for cold emails, which are people who I don't know, who don't come warmly recommended through our network.
The bar for those is just much higher.
Like, the story has to be more clear.
The hook has to better.
But that would be true if you were in a sales job and you were trying to reach out to any potential customer cold.
The quality of your communication has to better when the relationship is weaker.
But I don't know, I, I don't assume that everybody who I need to meet knows me or knows somebody who knows me.

And so every month I'm trying to figure out what's the right balance between people that I know that are coming and want me referred and people who seem really qualified through, outside of my network.
Do you open your email?
No.
No, I, I can't.
It's on the hours today.
No answer.
Simple.
Somebody Charles calls me up and says, I got this amazing company.
I know the founder well, and as he called it, I like that word, the metadata.
Right.
Like this is like the unique insight or the, or the understanding or the learnings that this founder has been doing.
He's an amazing person.
You guys should take the meeting.
And I could care less if he's working on like something I've been burned in or something else.
Like, usually when a person tells me that I'll take the meeting and it's worth my time and even if I don't invest, I've been so fortunate enough to meet somebody interesting, fascinating.
That teaches me something I didn't know before, where I sat there going, oh, that's a really interesting insight.
Let me think about that some more.
And then the other thing is, I never like taking meetings where I can't be helpful to the person.
Right.
If there's an introduction, I can do a new incentive, give them.
I work spent.
I spent 50 years on Google, 10 of them building the ad system and, you know, working on products like YouTube or like Google Voice or.
I started Google Analytics.
There's some product insight that I want to be helpful to person with.
Right.
Like, last thing I want to do is like, sit through a meeting with somebody and just sort of like, okay, thank you for coming.
I have nothing to tell you.
Right.
And so, like, because of that and the time constraints that we have, there's only maybe eight to 10 hours in the day that we can take meetings with.
Usually it has to come from somebody that says, this is the founder.
I have experience from them.
Here's the metadata.
Right.
The worst thing that could happen is somebody comes up in a conference call.
I've never met you, but I'm desperate to get my idea in front of you.
Hey, can you meet with me?
I don't think I've ever invested in a company that's come out cold.
Maybe I'm an idiot for that.
I don't know.
In about five minutes, we'll start thinking questions from the audience.
You can start lining up.
So if you don't open your email, how does the founder, who has no connection, no pedigree, they may be living in Australia.
That was the situation, obviously, Right.
How can they reach you?
How can they get.
They found a connection.
I mean, let's be honest, I did not know Cliff and L, but they, There was a.
There was a wonderful connection through a founder.
I invested and they knew it.
And that was very serendipitous.
But had that not happened, I probably wouldn't not have invested.
Right.
Because I wouldn't have found them.
And I have to be open to the possibility that there is some serendipity that occurs from being at a conference or meeting somebody randomly.
But I've not my 15 years of doing this, I've not found somebody.
Either the bar is too high or my defenses are too high or something else of that sort where I've been able to find that a good use of time.
We've done a few things that are cold.
They've actually been pretty good.
I will say though, we get a lot of referrals from founders that we met and passed on and to me that's still a relationship.
Like I have founders that we've passed on, where I've gone to Wesley's Point, tried to make introductions for them to be helpful.
Other people have been like, hey, I know you didn't invest, but the experience of meeting you was like pretty pleasant.
You listened to my pitch, you appear to be paying attention and you actually close the loop and told me why you weren't investing.
Which sadly, in our business I think puts you probably in the top quartile.

And I value those introductions too, because part of I know there's a whole thing about introduction, part of the nice thing about getting introduction from someone who knows what I do is I know that they know what I do.
They're not going to send me a series D rare Earth company that's raising $500 million at 5 billion because that's not what we do in precursor.

One, does a person have raw intellectual horsepower?

That wisdom is something that we look for and it typically is in older founders or people that had a couple sort of like scar tissue things under their belt.
